testimony.name: Joann Ariola
key_points: The City of Yes would be an unmitigated disaster in its current form
Current building regulations exist to protect quality of life
Homeowners deserve to raise families in the environment they bought into
The proposal would devastate quality of life for many taxpayers and residents
It would eliminate community input via ULURP
It favors large developers over small businesses and homeowners
New Yorkers deserve a say in their neighborhoods
Advocating for smart, sustainable development that doesn't destroy suburban community character
Concerns about preserving one and two-family homes and mom-and-pop shops
Not opposed to creating more housing, but wants it done in a smarter and more sustainable manner

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: But there are other suburban communities throughout the borough of Queens and throughout the Five boroughs. Where people bought because they are in 1 and 2 family homes. There are mom and pop shops and not mega stores that have come into the areas that oftentimes don't have the investment in the community that a mom and pop would have
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote indirectly addresses the Town Center Zoning element by discussing the character of suburban communities with 1 and 2 family homes and small businesses, which is relevant to the proposal's aim to legalize housing above businesses on commercial streets in low-density areas.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: Where people bought because they are in 1 and 2 family homes. There are mom and pop shops and not mega stores that have come into the areas that oftentimes don't have the investment in the community that a mom and pop would have or people who are 1 and 2 family homeowners and not and and wanna live in an area that doesn't have skyscrapers and lots of rentals.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote indirectly relates to the Transit-Oriented Development element by discussing the current character of low-density areas with 1 and 2 family homes, which contrasts with the proposal's aim to allow 3- to 5-story apartment buildings near public transit.
